column1: The city incorporated in 1965 by combining the previously unincorporated communities of Al Tahoe
column6: and Tallac Village. A post office was established in 1967.Gambling arrived at the Lake in 1944
column7: when Harvey's Wagon Wheel Saloon and Gambling Hall opened in Nevada as one of the area's first gaming establishments. Competition soon sprang up and so did the need for more permanent accommodations. By the 1950s
column8: roads began to be plowed year-round
column9: enabling access to permanent residences. When the 1960 Winter Olympics came to Squaw Valley
column10: Lake Tahoe was put firmly on the map as the skiing center of the western United States.

column1: South Lake Tahoe is served by a major east–west highway
column3: which links the area with Sacramento
column5: Nevada.  The Lake Tahoe Airport serves general aviation while the closest scheduled passenger airline service is available via the Reno–Tahoe International Airport in Reno

column1: South Lake Tahoe has a snowy highland climate featuring chilly winters with regular snowfall
column2: and summers that feature warm to hot days and cool nights with very low humidity. The climate is either classified as a warm-summer Mediterranean climate (Köppen Csb)
column3: using the 27 °F (−2.8 °C) isotherm of the original Köppen scheme
column4: or a continental Mediterranean climate (Köppen Dsb)
column5: using the 32 °F (0 °C) isotherm preferred by some climatologists. Summertime is also the dry season
column6: with July averaging only 0.31 inches (7.9 mm) of precipitation
column7: in contrast to December's 3.81 inches or 96.8 millimeters. Depending on the year
column8: snowfall can be extremely heavy in winter
column9: with an average of 107 inches or 2.72 meters
column10: while the wettest “rain year” has been from July 2005 to June 2006 with 31.12 inches (790.4 mm) and the driest from July 2002 to June 2003 with 9.26 inches (235.2 mm). December 2005 has been the wettest month with 13.83 inches (351.3 mm) of total water-equivalent precipitation.

column1: South Lake Tahoe averages two days per year that reach 90 °F or 32.2 °C or higher
column2: most commonly occurring in July and August. Every month of the year averages at least two nights with a low temperature of 32 °F or 0 °C or lower
column3: and overall there are 227 mornings in an average year that fall below freezing
column4: although only seven fall to 0 °F or −17.8 °C. High temperatures below 32 °F (0 °C) occur on average on sixteen days per year. The all-time record high is 99 °F (37.2 °C)
column7: and the all-time record low is −29 °F (−33.9 °C)

column3: a wildfire broke out at the Seneca Pond recreation area near Meyers
column4: three miles south of South Lake Tahoe.  The Angora Fire
column5: so named for its proximity to Angora Ridge
column6: stands as the worst forest fire in recorded Lake Tahoe history.The fire spread throughout the Angora region rapidly
column7: destroying dozens of homes and large tracts of forest. Highway closures followed by evacuations put the residents in the direct line of the fire. Hotels in the area responded by opening their doors to the hundreds of evacuees who needed shelter.

column3: a state of emergency was announced by Lt. Gov. John Garamendi acting on behalf of the absent Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger
column4: who was traveling in Europe. No lives were lost
column5: but over three thousand acres (12.5 square kilometers) were burned while more than 275 structures
column7: were damaged or destroyed. On June 27
column9: Schwarznegger toured the area after he returned to California.Full containment of the fire was announced on July 2.
